image.altText: Model pic sent to scam victims

props.synopsis: In the Dubai desert lies a scam factory capable of swindling tens of thousands of people at a time. But one scammer has a secret plan that could shut the whole syndicate down.

title.children: Inside a secret scam factory where workers pretend to be glamorous models

image.altText: A graphic of a nuclear power plant with a nuclear symbol and the numbers 2040 and 2045 in the foreground

props.synopsis: As the shift away from fossil fuels gathers pace, the Coalition has turned to an emissions-free technology with a long and contentious history — nuclear fission. These are the numbers you should keep in mind when thinking about its place in Australia’s energy transition.

title.children: Would a nuclear power plant fit Australia's needs? These numbers cut through the debate

image.altText: An Israeli military convoy

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council has backed plans for an Israel-Gaza ceasefire and Hamas has welcomed the resolution, saying it will cooperate with mediators.

title.children: UN Security Council backs plan for Israel-Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: A drone shot of housing development and green pastures, divided by a single road.

props.synopsis: Developers are building half-width streets in western Sydney due to current planning laws, as local councils and the state government blame each other over the issues the narrow roads are creating for residents.

title.children: NSW government and councils blame one another over 'absurd' half-width streets

image.altText: An illustration of a middle-aged man with black hair and a moustache, against an orange background

props.synopsis: Robert Baudin printed around $2 million in fake US notes. When he (eventually) faced court, he took to the air and threatened to crash into Sydney Harbour.

title.children: This man told his wife he was printing pornography. What he was doing was much more sinister

image.altText: Nicola, right, looks longingly at Luke, left, who lightly touches her face while outside in the evening.

props.synopsis: Australians are being warned this tax time not to double dip on working-from-home claims, make sure they have detailed records of expenses and not to lodge their tax returns too early.

title.children: 'Dos and don'ts this tax time': Use the internet to watch Bridgerton on Netflix? ATO warns you can't claim that as a deduction

image.altText: A composite image of Sam Short and Cate Campbell.

props.synopsis: The number of high-profile swimmers developing cancer is prompting a dermatologist to call for all major pools to be shaded by the 2032 Brisbane Olympics.

title.children: These swimmers have their sights set on the Olympics. They're also more likely to develop cancer

image.altText: Climate change demonstrators hold placards during a march outside the Houses of Parliament in London.

props.synopsis: The Coalition insists it supports the global Paris Agreement but it wants to dump Australia's short-term emissions reduction target. Is that allowed under the rules?

title.children: The Coalition's preparing to 'dump' Australia's 2030 climate target if it wins the next election. This is uncharted territory

image.altText: A woman wearing a red blazer smiles, standing in front of an art piece with a red heart.

props.synopsis: Recovery from these surgeries can take six months, something doctors hope could be alleviated by new technology.

title.children: Elle has had five open heart surgeries. She's hoping a new 'heart band-aid' may make the next one easier

image.altText: composite of three people

props.synopsis: A group of Canberrans including a protesting nun, a volunteering dentist and the CEO of a domestic violence service are among this year's recipients of King's Birthday Honours.

title.children: Canberra nun, dentist and CEO receive King's Birthday Honours

image.altText: A man sits on a rock in the snow.

props.synopsis: In a play for legitimacy in the eyes of the rest of the world, the Taliban is looking to reignite Afghanistan's tourism industry. Some Australians are taking up the invitation.

title.children: Are the Taliban using tourism to shed the tag of 'pariah state'?

image.altText: A woman looks on with her hands behind her head.

props.synopsis: The A-League owners pushed for the split away from Football Australia, but they left the sport's governing body with the three biggest money-spinners: the Matildas, Socceroos and grassroots football. Now the professional league is at risk of collapse.

title.children: Divided they fall: Why the A-League may need an urgent reunion with Football Australia

image.altText: A woman looks down at a wooden box while her hand is placed on it.

props.synopsis: Experts estimate there are hundreds of real human skeletons in Australian homes, with no clear pathway to hand them into authorities. One medical doctor is calling on universities to lead the solution.

title.children: Katrina's family has owned a human skeleton for decades. Now she's invested in its future

image.altText: A group of protestsers in front of Germany's parliament at a demonstration against the far-right Alternative for Germany.

props.synopsis: Radical-right political parties have made significant gains in the European Parliament elections, as nationalist and populist groups continue to gain dominance in national settings across EU capitals.

title.children: What is the far right? Why nationalist parties are on the rise in Europe

image.altText: A man speaking with his arm raised, standing at a green seat.

props.synopsis: As tensions simmer in Canberra over serious criminals keeping their Australian visas, figures show the tribunal that reviews those cases has been increasingly overturning cancellations for years in cases where someone's character is being questioned.

title.children: Direction 99 lit the fuse, but Australia's problems deporting serious criminals have festered for years

image.altText: Donald Trump and Malcolm Turnbull

props.synopsis: Malcolm Turnbull warns that a second Donald Trump White House would only be emboldened by the former president's legal troubles and that an Australian PM must stand their ground.

title.children: 'Trump is a bully': Turnbull opens up on what a second Trump presidency would mean

image.altText: A police helicopter searches the ocean.

props.synopsis: Three women have been swept off the rocks at Kurnell in the Sutherland Shire, sparking a major emergency response. One woman managed to make it back to shore but the other two were pronounced dead after being pulled unconscious from the ocean.

title.children: Two women dead after being swept off rocks in Sydney's south

image.altText: A "for lease" sign on a suburban street.

props.synopsis: The Australian Information Commissioner found TICA's controversial "virtual manager" service, which allows real estate agents to track tenants indefinitely, was subject to the same restrictions as the company's formal tenancy blacklist.

title.children: Information watchdog finds tenancy database breached renter's privacy by tracking their applications for seven years

image.altText: BEATLES ADELAIDE GETTY JEFF HOCHBERG

props.synopsis: In 1963, the world's musical landscape was changing, thanks to four young men from Liverpool. And one meeting in July that year made sure that Australia would not be left out.

title.children: How a man who'd barely heard of The Beatles got them to Australia 60 years ago

image.altText: Two small elephants intertwine trunks next to a water body

props.synopsis: Wild elephants may be able to communicate with other members of their group by using sounds akin to names, a new study suggests.

title.children: Do elephants call each other by name, just like humans?

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus smiles

props.synopsis: Nervous energy cackles through the Brisbane Aquatic Centre ahead of the Australian Olympic trials, and nobody is immune from its effect.

title.children: 'I was just dead silent': Australia's best swimmers on overcoming the paralysing fear of nerves

image.altText: Two young white kids holding hands, running through long grass

props.synopsis: Studies suggest the absence of "risky play" in the modern world could be contributing to the teen mental health crisis. Here's what it's all about.

title.children: What is 'risky play' and what benefits does it have for kids?

image.altText: Jack Gunston of the Hawthorn Hawks, Zac Williams of Carlton and Christian Petracca of Melbourne Demons in round 13 of the AFL.

props.synopsis: Carlton reasserts itself as a premiership contender, Hawthorn continues an incredible run of form, and alarm bells continue ringing for Melbourne. Here are the talking points from Round 13 in the AFL.

title.children: AFL Round-Up — Blues teach Bombers a lesson, Hawks continue rising as Demons flounder again

image.altText: A composite image of NRL players, Kotoni Staggs in pain, Brian To'o celebrating and Jack Wighton running

props.synopsis: The Panthers send a warning shot to rivals, Brisbane suffers another collapse and Souths find their mojo. Here are the biggest talking points from every game of round 14.

title.children: NRL Round-Up — Broncos lose another second half as the Rabbitohs finally find theirs

image.altText: Michelle Pearson sings on stage.

props.synopsis: Adelaide-born Michelle Pearson will perform her new show Skinny at the Adelaide Cabaret Festival with a powerful message about the dangers of unhealthy body image.

title.children: Cabaret performer tackles 'cruelty' of unhealthy body image with new show Skinny

image.altText: framed images of the victims of the Hunter Valley bus crash

props.synopsis: Twelve months after the Hunter Valley bus crash claimed the lives of 10 people, affected communities and first responders are still coming to terms with the tragedy.

title.children: 'People grieve in different ways': Emotions still raw a year after the Hunter Valley bus crash

image.altText: backpackers

props.synopsis: Backpackers fear a rise in exploitation on Australian farms after the government axed a 26-year-old jobs program, which farmers fear will also increase costs and threaten harvests.

title.children: End of 'go-to' harvest trail farm labour program a big loss, farmers say

image.altText: People watch on at the Territory Day fireworks celebrations at Mindil Beach in 2021.

props.synopsis: The fireworks party, one of the biggest events on the NT calendar, will be moved from Mindil Beach because the NT Major Events Company has not obtained an authority certificate from the NT's sacred sites watchdog.

title.children: For the first time in 20 years, the NT's Territory Day fireworks won't be held at its most iconic beach

image.altText: A photo showing people holding disposable cups and plates.

props.synopsis: Despite having the greatest need for funding in Australia, with a homelessness rate 12 times the national average, the NT has persistently not received enough Commonwealth money because of its small population. But in May, that changed.

title.children: 'Game changing' federal funding is chance to finally start fixing homelessness in the NT, advocates say

image.altText: A woman with flannel shirt, brown hair and dark features looks pensively into the camera with a pride flag in background.

props.synopsis: Living in a derelict rental is causing a lot of stress for Natalie as she eyes off a university degree.

title.children: With possum poo in her rental home, Natalie's goal to break the cycle of poverty is fraught with barriers

image.altText: Peter Costello wears a dark jacket and a check shirt

props.synopsis: The failure of Peter Costello to properly address his run-in with a journalist at Canberra Airport has ended his long tenure at the media company and handed a "toxic baton" to his replacement, writes Peter Ryan.

title.children: Peter Costello's 'brain fade' has brought his career at Nine to an end, and left his successor with a huge mess to clean up

image.altText: A drone shot of Port Lincoln, South Australia.

props.synopsis: In two years time this region of Australia could run out of drinking water but the solution is not in line with the wishes of one peak industry.

title.children: 'The water situation is dire': This city faces running out of water inside two years

image.altText: Michael Mosley speaks on a morning talk show wearing a blazer, blue shirt and glasses

props.synopsis: The disappearance of Dr Michael Mosley caught the world's attention. The days-long search operation ended when a cameraman spotted "something black" on the rocks that had been searched "I don't know how many times".

title.children: 'Exactly the guy we're looking for': How the search for Michael Mosley unfolded

image.altText: A man selling the catch of the day sits among the hustle of a vibrant fresh market in Pondicherry, India.

props.synopsis: A fisherman in Burma, a winery in France, and a wedding party in China are among the winning shots in this year's Food Photography Awards.

title.children: Steamy dim sum feast takes out top gong in this year's Food Photography Awards
